IRD_activities.activity: Multi-religious Collaboration for the Common Good: This programme equips, engages and mobilises faith leaders, congregations, faith-based institutions, interreligious councils and individuals. Focuses on Uganda.

The KAICIID Fellows Programme: Coming from different regions and different faiths, these students will spend some time working and studying together in Vienna to deepen their knowledge about the Other and to strengthen their commitment to interreligious dialogue.

name_en: King Abdullah Bin Abdulaziz International Centre for Interreligious and Intercultural Dialogue
structure: Council of Parties (Three founding states Austria; Saudi Arabia; Spain); Board of Directors (high-level representatives of the major world religions (Judaism; Christianity; Islam; Hinduism and Buddhism); Secretariat (Secretary General is the head of the organization)
IRD_def: The importance of interreligious and intercultural dialogue is an instrument to address the religious and spiritual dimension of human beings and to, inter alia, support conflict prevention and resolution, sustainable peace and social  cohesion.
events: 2012: KAICIID Day
2013: KAICIID Global Forum: Image of the Other in Education
aim: Generate, develop and disseminate knowledge in the area of Interreligious and Intercultural dialogue. Cultivate and promote respect for differences through dialogue. Create bridges. Address conflict and promote collaboration amongst diverse groups.

languages: English, Spanish, Russian, Chinese, German, others.

events: Summary of their activities from April 2012-March 2013:                                        1. Educational Work: Conducted 2,914 cultural units, camps, workshops and seminars during the year in across 748 educational institutions with a total student population of more than 200,000
2. Medical Service: conducted 469 eye camps in rural areas and 424 general medical camps for the poor apart from specialised medical camps

3.Work in Rural and Tribal Areas: undertook pending projects of rural development. Relief: During natural or man-made disasters, the Mission’s work includes primary relief with food, clothes, medicine and permanent relief activities like construction of new full-fledged townships, bridges, and roads, sometimes a project going over Rs. 150 million
4.Publication: The Mission’s publication centres produce some of the best publications on religion, philosophy, and spiritual culture.  The total turnover in 2004-05 was Rs. 86 million

5. Spreading Religion and Culture: The Math and Mission spread the spiritual teachings and cultural ideals through a large number of public libraries, lectures, discourses and seminars, audio-visual units, exhibitions, museums, retreats and publishing books, journals, etc. conducted 24,863 classes and lectures, 495 retreats and 1,207 celebrations and public meetings.
structure: 1.The Ramakrishna Math is administered by a Board of Trustees. The Board of Trustees has an elected President, one or more Vice-Presidents, a General Secretary, one or more Assistant Secretaries and a Treasurer; 2.The Ramakrishna Mission is administered by a Governing Body, which is composed of the Trustees of Ramakrishna Math. The headquarters of Ramakrishna Math at Belur (popularly known as Belur Math) itself serves as the headquarters of Ramakrishna Mission; The current team consists of 21 members-One President, three vice-presidents, One General Secretary, four assistant Secretaries, One Treasurer and Eleven other members.
IRD_def: Inspired by the idea of the harmony of all faiths, the centers encourage adherents of different faiths to meet in a spirit of friendship and mutual appreciation, and to learn from one another without having to give up one's own faith. In the words of Sri Ramakrishna: "God has made different religions to suit different aspirants, lives and countries (...) all doctrines are only so many paths; but a path is by no means God Himself. Indeed one can reach God if one follows any of the paths with whole-hearted devotion."
finances: voluntary donations,government grants, income from running schools, hospitals, etc.
aim: 1. Promote spiritual knowledge, inter-faith harmony and social welfare through service; enable one's own liberation and the welfare of the world; 2.To spread the idea of harmony of religions based on Sri Ramakrishna's experience that all religions lead to the realization of the same Reality known by different names in different religions.The Mission honours and reveres the founders of all world religions such as Buddha, Christ and Mohammed; 3.To treat all work as worship, and service to man as service to God; 4.To make all possible attempts to alleviate human suffering by spreading education, rendering medical service, extending help to villagers through rural development centres, etc.; 5.To work for the all-round welfare of humanity, especially for the uplift of the poor and the downtrodden; 6.To develop harmonious personalities by the combined practice of Jnana, Bhakti, Yoga and Karma.
publications: Many books on three main themes--Scriptures, Ramakrishna-Vivekananda literature and General topics. The Math has its own publishing centres (11) numerous journals in various languages from different centres published (http://www.belurmath.org/publication1.htm)

general_activities.activity_description: 15 hospitals (with 2182 beds), 125 dispensaries, and 48 mobile medical units which treat about 8,000,000 patients every year. Besides these, a considerable number of medical camps are organized, mostly in rural areas, where thousands of patients are treated and more than 3000 operated on for cataract free of cost every year. The Math and Mission run a medical research institute and 5 nurses' training centres;

general_activities.activity_name: Work in Rural and Tribal Areas
general_activities.activity_description: For rural and tribal people, institutes of agriculture and 4 rural development training institutes are run; farmers taught improved methods of cultivation and provided with agricultural inputs and financial help. Projects such as construction of pucca (permanent) houses, wasteland development, planting of fruit and forest trees, etc are undertaken. Drinking water is provided by digging bore wells and tube wells;

During natural or man-made disasters, the Mission’s work includes primary relief with food, clothes, medicine and permanent relief activities like construction of new full-fledged townships, bridges, and roads, sometimes a project going over Rs. 150 million; 5.Publication: The Mission’s publication centres produce some of the best publications on religion, philosophy, and spiritual culture. The total turnover in 2004-05 was Rs. 86 million.

The Math and Mission spread the spiritual teachings and cultural ideals through a large number of public libraries, lectures, discourses and seminars, audio-visual units, exhibitions, museums, retreats and publishing books, journals, etc. Books on Vedanta, the message of Sri Ramakrishna, Holy Mother Sarada Devi and Swami Vivekananda, spirituality and world religions in almost all the major languages of India and in some of the important languages of other countries are published form the 21 publication centres of the Math and Mission.

history: Brought into existence by Sri Ramakrishna (1836-1886), a 19th century saint from Bengal and his chief disciple, Swami Vivekananda (1863-1902). The Math and Mission together comprises the Ramakrishna Movement which is also referred to as the Vedanta Movement. Registered in 1901.

structure: Charismatic personality Swami Chidanand Saraswati is the founder of IHRF; This is a Personality based organisation, assisted by lay devotees and numerous people volunteering for the projects and programmes
other_relations: Founder also co-founded Global Interfaith WASH Alliance (Water, Sanitation, Hygiene) GIWA
IRD_def: The key to having world-wide cultural awareness and inter-ethnic sensitivity is by having events meant for Inter-Faith harmony--like conferences, gatherings and youth summer camps
events: IHRF organizes a variety of conferences, gatherings and youth summer camps to heighten world-wide cultural awareness and inter-ethnic sensitivity
1. July 2003: inagurated an Ashram (monastery/Inn) on the banks of Lake Mansarova. It has 20 rooms for pilgrims who make a trip to the Hindu holy place
2. 2004: A medical camp was conducted at Mansarovar by a team of 40 volunteer doctors from the USA
Plans to have it on an annual basis
3. Two other Ashrams--(monastery/Inn)  one each in India and Tibet were inagurated (2006, 2009) to cater to the needs of the Hindu travellers on their pilgimage to Mount Kailash, Mansarovar
4. Health Camps: conducted various camps across the region
5. Orphanages and Schools for the children of the region
inagurated a computer centre
6. Tsumani relief-constructing temporary houses for the affected
7. Publications: Various books by Swami
aim: The organisation seeks to strive for a better world; works in the field of education, medical projects, environmental programmes, humanitarian aid projects and InterFaith exchange;
publications: Other books written by Chidanand Saraswati-'By God
s Grace' (autobiography), In the Lap of Maa Ganga, Peace, Vegetarianism, Drops of Nectar and other titles.

structure: Based on the charismatic leadeship of Geshe Thupten Phelgyen, a buddhist monk, and assisted by student monks, lay volunteers and devotees.

aim: Primarily aimed at creating awareness and practicing Compassion--especially towards animals. The long-range goals of UCF are global concerns, such as promoting world peace, interfaith harmony, protection and conservation of the environment, “the mother earth” giving a helping hand to destitute children in their education and any such programmes of necessary assistance, who would otherwise be left suffering great difficulties in their struggles to survive.However, the present activities listed on the website are confined to raising funds to support monks.

name_en: The Global Alliance for Interfaith Action (GAIA)
structure: Based on Volunteer action; even President works probono; Publicly supported:depends on contributions and grants
IRD_def: GAIA appreciates the value of intercultural and interfaith dialogue as a bridge-builder, but GAIA is not a talk-oriented initiative: GAIA is about putting compassion into action-They bring people together, across historical boundaries in active altruistic collaboration, usually in the form of volunteer service and other such activities.
events: 1. Oct and Dec 2014: Open Volunteer Period for Sustainable Living in the Himalayas
2. Oct 2014 Meditation with Horses—Catalonia, Spain
3.July 2014: Deep Rest Retreat with Open Dharma in California
4.June 2014: Deep Rest Retreat — Le Moulin, France
5. May 2014: Open Dharma Events in Israel
6.Being Peace Service Retreat in Israel & Palestine, various dates in 2011,2012,2013
7. Jan 2013: Sulha Tribal Fire: A Gathering for Peace in the Middle East
8. Other Volunteer and service learning programmes
Meditation programmes
Concerts
Public Talks and Presentations
Conferences and Dialogues (not confined to GAIA but the various Earthville projects)
aim: GAIA appreciates the value of intercultural and interfaith dialogue as a bridge-builder, but GAIA is not a talk-oriented initiative: GAIA is about putting compassion into action- They bring people together, across historical boundaries, in active altruistic collaboration, usually in the form of volunteer service and other such activities; The premise, which their experience since 1997 consistently supports, is that when people from distant backgrounds (geographic, cultural, or belief) come together in selfless service of another, great things can happen.
history: Founded informally in 1997 in the India; Incorporated in California in 2000 as a 501(c)(3) public charity; (tax exemption for donations)

structure: A part of the catholic order (Jesuits) with its own hierarchy; Some key persons associated with this are clergy; others are volunteers from their churches,etc;
IRD_def: To understand the significance and the need for entering into dialogue with anyone of good will, especially in the context of religious conflicts, and encourage them to work together toward trust and co-operation, peace and harmony of life.
events: No information
aim: Fostering Interreligious dialogue at various levels and attempts to make interreligious dialogue an essential dimension of their One Mission; Translating this on the practical level for most Jesuits, it means that the Secretariat strives to help them, precisely as religiously committed persons, to understand the significance and the need for entering into dialogue with anyone of good will, especially in the context of religious conflicts, and encourage them to work together toward trust and co-operation, peace and harmony of life.
old_alias: Merging of the two previously existing secretariats-Secretariat for the Service of Faith and Religion in India (SEFRI) and the Secretariat for Jesuits Among Muslims in India (JAMI) became JSD
history: Started in 1994(merger of the former organisations;no further information)

IRD_activities.activity: Inter-Faith Congregation of Muslims and Hindus called 'Sneh Milan' organised in Feb 2014 (http://www.artofliving.org/ontourwithsrisri-sneh-milan-exchanging-genuine-love-and-belongingness); 6.Attended the Dialogue between Civilizations and Cultures Conference held in May 2014;

structure: Based on the charismatic religious leadership of Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, AOLF has a board of trustees with a term of two years with two-thirds of the trustees changed every two years. All AOL teachers and the previous trustees are allowed to nominate a new board. There is a provision for an advisory board that monitors and guides the organisation. All the accounts are regularly audited by an external auditor. Other than expenses, no trustee is entitled to benefits in terms of salary, etc. Art of Living programs directly help to fund its humanitarian projects.The proceeds from the sales of The Art of Living Publications and Ayurveda products are also directed to our social initiatives.Apart from the above two boards,AOLF is assisted by lay devotees and volunteers.
other_relations: The Art of Living has a few sister organisations which are also dedicated to the vision of a stress-free, violence-free world. The International Association for Human Values (IAHV), Ved Vignan Maha Vidya Peeth (VVMVP), Sri Sri RaviShankar Vidya Mandir (SSRVM), Vyakti Vikas Kendra India (VVKI), Sri Sri Rural Development Program (SSRDP) and Sri Sri Institute of Agricultural Sciences & Technology Trust (SSIAST) among others, formulate and implement humanitarian projects of The Art of Living globally.
IRD_def: IRD  is understood by the AOLF as the philosophy of Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, who  has devoted himself to promoting composite dialogue between conflicting parties across the world. Over the past three decades, he has opened up channels of communications, mediated in and facilitated meaningful dialogue; The key to inter-faith harmony and to reducing terrorism, according to Sri Sri Ravi Shankar, lies in education – a multi-cultural education that encourages cultural pluralism.
events: Yoga camps, happiness programme (meditation). Art of Meditation (Sahaj Samadhi) Course, Sudarshan Kriya (yoga)
The Art of Living runs the courses all year round in various locations
AOLF attended and represents in many Inter Faith conferences around the world

The Art of Living—Projects Management Unit (PMU) is a special technical wing within The Art of Living that implements holistic solutions for social, economic and environmental issues. The goal is to enable transformation by acting as intermediary between various resource providers and communities.These connections combined with our empowerment, accountability and sustainability models, enable a lasting impact towards our shared goals

under empowerment programme, Youth Leadership Training Program (YLTP) transform ‘vulnerable’ young men and women into leaders in their communities. They become proactive ‘advocates’ for change and ‘owners’ of their challenges. AOLF work with these empowered leaders toward complete development of their communities.
aim: AOLF’s programs are guided by Sri Ravi Shankar's philosophy: “Unless we have a stress-free mind and a violence-free society, we cannot achieve world peace.” AOLF offers self-development programs and tools that facilitate the elimination of stress and foster deep and profound inner peace, like breathing techniques, meditation, and yoga;  In addition to these courses offered globally, AOLF, working in collaboration with The International Association for Human Values (IAHV), has successfully implemented numerous humanitarian projects and service initiatives including conflict resolution programs, disaster relief, sustainable rural development, empowerment of women, prisoner rehabilitation, education for all, and environmental sustainability.
history: Started in 1981 by a Charismatic Religious leader, Sri Sri Ravi Shankar in India; The US and Germany centres were formed in 1989; later spread to many other countries.

IO_relations: Member of the International Association for Religious Freedom (IARF) and the International Association of Liberal Religious Women (IALRW)

United Religious Initiative (URI),International Association of Liberal Religious Women (IALRW),  International Association of Educators for World Peace (IAEWP), Elijha Interfaith Instutute and Museum of World Religion

structure: Headed by the charismatic founder and spiritual Director of the MIMC Bikku Sanghasena, who is also a Buddhist religious leader. The structure is composed of a  'sangha' a core group of leadership, assisted by the community of monks and nuns, students, elderly and disabled, staff and volunteers
IRD_def: Guru Sangasena Mahanayaka Thera emphasizes that "Different religions should be considered like different flowers; The colours and shapes of flowers may be different, but all are flowers nevertheless; The more flowers that exist in the garden, the more beautiful that garden will be; The teachings of all the religions are sacred and are but facets of one truth."
events: 1.International Festival of Buddhist Heritage of Ladakh, an annual festival organised by MIMC since 2012
2.Organised the World Fellowship of Buddhist Youth Regional Seminar in 2004

3.Organised in association with International Association for Religious Freedom (IARF) Ladakh group, one day Inter-Faith Seminar "Preservation of Religious Harmony, Co-existence and Universal Peace" in 2005
4.Three day conference on "Conflict Resolution of Buddhist-Muslim Dialogue" was held by MIMC in association with IARF and other groups in 2010

5.MIMC spear heads the interfaith programmes in Ladakh by inviting different religious heads and international organizations working in the direction of peace, harmony and dialogue between religious groups for world Peace
the founder also goes to various international  fora to give lectures on inter religious harmony.
aim: A dedicated team of social workers, teachers, doctors, monks, nuns, community leaders and care-providers have created an integrated community at Devachan in Ladakh which provides comprehensive care to all segments of society: children, elderly, special needs individuals, monks & nuns, the sick, as well as those seeking spiritual development; The community has become a model for the region through sustainable, ecological development. With the support of their sponsors. They hope to be able to contribute our part to this goal by serving the people of Ladakh.
history: A charismatic buddhist leader, Bhikkhu Sanghasena established the Mahabodhi International Meditation Center in 1986

structure: Founded by the charismatic buddhist female leader Thubten Chodron; Assisted by lay devotees and volunteers
IRD_def: Interreligious dialogue helps us to approach people of different faiths—or no particular faith—with an open mind, respect, and willingness to learn. Through such conversations, we become more open-minded and our abilities to investigate and examine our own beliefs and ourselves sharpen. While there are philosophical differences between religions, we can recognize those and still appreciate the similarities; All spiritually-oriented people admire the qualities of love, compassion, wisdom, generosity, and ethical behavior that is based on non-harmfulness. When we meet each other in the spirit of these shared values, we increase understanding, encourage harmony among the followers of various faiths, and contribute to creating peace throughout our chaotic world.
events: Events conducted round-the-year--Vajrasattva New Year’s retreat
Annual Winter Retreat:Four Establishments of Mindfulness
The Power of Love retreat
How to See Yourself as You Really Are retreat
Annual Young Adults Explore Buddhism course
Apart from a regular Monastery activitiy (Studying Buddhism through teaching, discussions, and meditation activities)
the abbey conducts 'Share The Dharma Day' one Sunday in a month and encourages inter faith outreach.
aim: The Abbey's mission is to nurture a flourishing monastic community in the US, where learning and practicing Buddha's ancient teachings cultivate peace in the hearts of the residents and visitors and, by extension, in the world.
history: Started in 2003 by charismatic buddhist female leader Thubten Chodron; Aimed at nurturing a flourishing Buddhist monastic community in the US. Chodron is originally an  American and travelled to Asia to study Buddhism.

structure: Founded by the charismatic Hindu Vedanta teacherSwami Dayananda Saraswati; Assisted by lay devotees and volunteers
IRD_def: Respecting cultural and religious diversity is extremely important in contemporary times, and can be a cornerstone for the elimination of most conflict; Indigenous and ethnic religious and spiritual traditions, including Hinduism, have an impressive history of accommodation and religious tolerance. An important mission of the Arsha Vijnana Gurukulum is to foster peace between peoples and nations; Starting from the Vedanta philosophy of self-acceptance, to the acceptance of others and ultimately the world.
events: 1. Numerous events/courses on studying and understanding Vedanta that take place around the year

2.Developing graduate and under-graduate residential credit courses in yoga, meditation, Ayurveda, Vedanta and Sanskrit to university students across the United States based on the quarter or the semester systems
3.Online Vedanta classes
aim: 1.To serve as a institute or seat of learning for the transmission of the Vedic tradition of the ancient sages, especially Vedanta and Sanskrit; 2.To bridge an important gap in the proper understanding of the Vedic tradition for the Indian community in the Southern Region of the United States; 3.To disseminate the understanding of the religious and spiritual heritage of India by promoting study, research, and discussion; 4.To house the Global Diversity Coalition of Religious and Spiritual Leaders, an organization dedicated to serve as a unifying force for all indigenous traditions of the world;  In conjunction with the Global Diversity Coalition of Religious and Spiritual Leaders Promoting the MDGs, Arsha Vijnana Gurukulum will serve as an important seat for the protection of such endangered traditions and knowledge bases that promote a holistic worldview, and ways of life conducive to fostering the awareness of the interconnectedness of humans and nature; 5.To network with other like-minded organizations in the area.
history: Arsha Vijnana Gurukulam was founded in March 2005 by Swami Dayananda Saraswati.

languages: English, Hindi, Urdu, Sinhala, Bengali, etc.

IRD_activities.activity: Organize volunteers across India, and train them through spiritual, social, economic, ecological and political awakening, instilling in them best spiritual standards of living, peace making and being sensitive to the society they live in and interact with;

publishes a quarterly multi-faith journal "Building Bridges" in order to take the concept of unity in diversity to the whole of India and to every corner of the world and, for this purpose, to network individuals and communities of diverse affiliations especially in India and abroad;

structure: Headed by a Board of Trustees (Governing Council) assisted by a Consultative Committee of Religious Readers. These are helped by President, Vice President and General Secretary; The next level are the regiional secretaries and others
IRD_def: The Interfaith Coalition for Peace, strongly appeals to the followers of all religions and faiths to work together for strengthening religious tolerance, mutual respect and peace, thus not only enhancing human dignity but also joining the chorus in praise of God.
events: 1. Mainly Seminars and Conferences
One of the charismatic leaders (Syed Zafar Mahmood)is involved in speaking at various inter-faith fora
2.Rally of Muslims, Christians and Scheduled Castes (so called 'low' castes), Lucknow, India:  20 April 2013
3.InterFaith Peace conferences and Conventions: Mangalore, India Feb 2013: Guwahati, Assam, Jan 2013
4.Workshop on Peace & Communal Harmony, Bubhaneshwar, India Jan 2013
5.Lecture on 'Perspectives on Peacemaking: Muslims & Christians in Constructive Conversation' New Delhi, India Feb 2012
aim: ICP seeks to enabling people achieve the full realization of their rights as human beings, attaining & sustaining equitable and dignified life. Simultaneously ICP is involved in non-formal interfaith, academic courses and advocacy of community care.

IO_relations: General Consultative Status NGO with UN's Economic and Social Council (1983)
Affiliation with UN Department of Public Information (in 1980)
languages: Hindi, English, Russian, German, and numerous languages wherever centres operate

finances: From Voluntary donations of devotees; government grants and funding for humanitarian projects

IRD_activities.activity: www.uri.org; 7.The World Council of Religious Leaders: This initiative grew out of the Millennium World Peace Summit of Religious and Spiritual Leaders held in August 2000 at the United Nations New York and addressed by Dadi Janki. www.millenniumpeacesummit.org; 8.The Global Peace Initiative of Women Religious and Spiritual Leaders: Brahma Kumaris support the Initiative's Women's Partnership for Peace in the Middle East and the Global Ethics and Universal Education for Values project. www.gpiw.org; 9.Council for a Parliament of the World's Religions:The Brahma Kumaris have played an active role in the Parliaments of the World's Religions and the Council’s Assembly of Religious Leaders in Chicago (1993) South Africa (1999) and Barcelona (2004), serving on the organizing committees and contributing to events;10.World Conference of Religions for Peace (WCRP): Brahma Kumaris are active in local chapters around the world. www.wcrp.org.

structure: Headed by three spiritual administrators. Assisted by 19 different wings that cover all the day to day administration as well as the programmes and plans. numerous BK teachers and lay volunteers and devotees also actively take part
IRD_def: Brahma Kumaris believe that a deeper understanding between faiths, based on acceptance and respect, will contribute to a culture of peace and non-violence in our world community.
events: Yoga and stress relieving courses conducted almost in all the centres on a regular basis
Observance of festivals
seminars and conferences
aim: BKs seek to help individuals re-discover and strengthen their inherent worth by encouraging and facilitating a process of spiritual awakening, leading to an awareness of the importance of thoughts and feelings as the seeds of actions. The development of virtues and values-based attitudes creates a practical spirituality which enhances personal effectiveness in the workplace and in family life. An understanding of the spiritual context of human existence is offered, helping to make sense of contemporary issues; Based on the principle that the roots of change lie within, the university encourages individuals to live by their highest values, vision and purpose. It holds that this commitment to self-transformation will create peace and a better world for all.
history: BKs was founded in 1936 in Hyderabad, Sindh (now part of Pakistan, but at that time part of colonial India) by Dada Lekhraj, who had a series of visions depicting world transformation. In 1937, he formed a managing committee of eight young women and established an informal group that grew into the Brahma Kumaris World Spiritual University.

languages: English, Urdu, Bhasa Indonesian, Hindi, Thai, Vietnamese.

IRD_def: All religions teach peace, justice, compassion for those who suffer, equality, love, human dignity and solidarity, non-violence, sensitivity to others and the oneness of the human family; We believe that humanity and nature are interdependent; However, we must humbly acknowledge that our own communities have often failed to be agents of peace and to live according to our shared values; Such a self-critical attitude must be accompanied by a love and renewed commitment to what is best in our own tradition, as well as genuine respect and esteem for the spiritual and humane values enshrined in all religions of the powerful.
events: 1.School of Peace: conducted on a regular basis since 2006: duration is between a week to three and half months
2.Conducts Festival of JustPeace at the end of the SOP: The festival attracts 1,500 people approximately.
aim: The basic goals of Interfaith Cooperation are to support a regional inter-religious Asian movement for justice and transformation that focuses on marginalized communities; confronts the roots of violence; and promotes justice in the economic, political, and social spheres; Objectives:1.Inter-religious Networking; 2.Inter-religious Information; 3.Inter-religious Activities for Justpeace; 4.Annual Inter-religious Cooperation programmes.
publications: 1. Book: Our Stories, Our Challenges: The Search for JustPeace in Asia Today
3. Consultative papers, perspectives and special reports
history: Origins traced to the Consultation meeting on Interfaith Cooperation in Asia, which was held in Prapat, North Sumatera, Indonesia from 5-10 April 2003; This was jointly organised by Asia Pacific Alliance of YMCAs (APAY), Christian Conference of Asia (CCA),and Church Development Service (EED), Germany.
